So, per Aristotle, a good “rule by many” regime is a “polity.” A democracy, on the other hand, is when you have rule by many, but those may still rule everything in their own favor, rather than for the public good. In other words, democracy is to polity as oligarchy is to aristocracy as tyranny is to kingship (where one person rules for the benefit of the many). I completely agree with this view.

This is exactly what Mr. McNevin (emphasizing this name slightly, with a slight air of disgust) meant when he said that he had read the Bible in a literary sense. Read it through once, taking it as a story, as literature, putting aside any preconceived notions

The greatness of the story, a Christmas Carol, requires that you believe in these ghosts as being integral to the story. It's not teach you a great moral truth about how you should be kind to poor people, but you actually need to experience the story the way he does, recognizing these ghosts teach him about all the wrong he's done in his life

That is a good point that he makes. If God had wanted us to experience the Bible through just the small points that we take out of it, then god could've just written those points. However, it's designed to be read as a story

This guy really despises Ayn Rand. He talks about how juvenile she is, making up her mind as a teen and holding it throughout her entire life, e.g. taking some silly songs and classifying them as among the greats like Beethoven, and he talks about how she borrowed a little over $1000 from her family in today’s dollars and never paid it back.
So, while he wildly disagrees with Ayn Rand’s life, he appears to agree with her views written in the book
At the 1962 American aesthetics Association, Rand presented a paper and was questioned. She didn't like this, and never allowed another interview again
